She gets her supplies in Bamako. She resells these items in cash and on credit, at home to a clientele composed of men and women in the different areas of the city of Bougouni.
With this loan, she foresees realizing an average monthly profit of 40,000 FCFA. This profit will allow her to pay the interest on her loan and invest in her business.
She intends to become a wholesaler in Bougouni in the future.

loans.use: To buy clothing, shoes, and ointments

loans.name: Salima

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Salima works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from direct selling Avon and Natashia products. Salima is borrowing 15,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell such as eggs, salt, onion, etc. for her general store business.

Salima has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell such as eggs, salt, onion, etc

loans.name: Cresilda

texts.en:
Cresilda is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her. She was able to buy more of the materials needed for foam making. Her loan helped not just with her business, but also with the education of her children. Her income is assisting their everyday household expenditures. She and her husband are working hard to provide for their everyday needs. 

She would like to apply for another 11,000 PHP loan for her to buy materials like foam, fabric, rugby and other materials needed to make foam beds. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and her children’s education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

She hopes to expand her business and dreams to give her family a good future. She meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of their lives and business every week. It is where she can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay their microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for materials like foam, fabric, rugby and other materials needed to make foam beds.

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Djiguiya est un regroupement de femmes de la ville de Koutiala qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 36 ans, sont mariées et ont au moins 5 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que, de Légumes, Condiments, Savons, Boissons, Plastique  et divers. Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso pour la première fois. 
Maïmouna  est un membre du groupe Djiguiya assise au bout et à  gauche, vendeuse de boisson (jus de tamarins, Bissape et d’Orange. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter de tamarins, Bissape et d’Orange au fur et à mesure qu’elle   transformera en boisson non alcoolisée. Elle se procure de ces produits à Koutiala. Elle les vend à la maison à une clientèle diverse. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Djiguiya comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 105 000CFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Mme Maïmouna compte réaliser  110 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses personnelles et augmenter son fonds de commerce. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcer ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en:
Djiguiya is a group of women from the city of Koutiala who live in large traditional households with their husbands, children, and other relatives. They are on average 36 years old, married, and have at least five children.
This group of women run businesses selling various items such as vegetables, condiments, soaps, drinks, plastic item and so on. To increase the size of their businesses, the members decided to join the loan program at Soro Yiriwaso for the first time.
Maïmouna, the Djiguiya group member sitting at the end on the left, sells fruit juices (made from tamarind, hibiscus, and oranges). She intends to use her loan to buy tamarind, hibiscus, and orange as she converts them into non-alcoholic drinks. She gets these products in Koutiala and sells them at home to a diverse clientele.
While the other Djiguiya group members intend to realize a monthly profit of 105,000 FCFA each during this loan cycle, Ms. Maïmouna intends to realize a monthly profit of 110,000 FCFA.
In addition to repaying their loans, the group members will use a portion of their income to pay for personal expenses and increase their capital.
They hope to strengthen this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso so that their stocks are not sparse.

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make fruit juice.

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
This is Josie, 46, a resident of Payatas, Philippines. She is married to Wilfredo, her business partner, and they have children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their household while running the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Josie sells bedding and mattresses. She makes and manufactures the bedding and mattresses with the help of her husband. Customers buy their products because they're cheaper than those in the mall. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 400 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, Josie is requesting a loan of 28,000 PHP. She will be using the loan to buy materials like foam, fabric, rugby and other materials needed in making foam beds.

Josie dreams of being more successful in business and dreams that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. It is a place where she can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for foam, fabric, and other materials needed in making foam beds.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married with five children; four of whom go to school. She has a business of a retail shop and has been in this business for five years. She has applied for a loan of 1,000,000 Uganda Shillings(UGX) from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap, rice, bands of bread, and beans. 

She works from home seven days out of every week, and sells on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include transportation and defaulters. She is aspiring of owning a fully stocked retail shop, and to educate her children by going to school. 

She resides in the family house, and the family has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and food for the family.

loans.use: to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap, rice, bands of bread, and beans.

loans.name: Merlie

texts.en:
Merlie is 40 years old and married with four children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a business buying and selling fish in the Philippines and requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock of fish to sell.

Merlie has borrowed and repaid 21 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running this business for eight years and earns additional income from her general store.

She aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more stock of fish to sell

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is a single mother of four children and only one goes to school. She also takes care of additional family members (mother). She has a business making and selling handbags and has been in this business for 15 years. She has applied for a loan of 1,500,000 Uganda shilling from MCDT-SACCO to buy more raw materials for making hand bags.  She works in her shop seven days out of every week and sells on a wholesale basis only. Her major business challenges include transportation and the ever-increasing price of raw materials.  She is aspiring to have a big factory making handbags. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials for making handbags.

loans.name: Krystel Ann

texts.en:
Krystel Ann is 24 years old and married with one children.

Krystel Ann works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more items, such as snack food, canned good, and other groceries.

Krystel Ann has borrowed and paid four loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years, and earns an income from food vending.

Krystel Ann aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase items, such as snack food, canned goods, and other groceries.

loans.name: Licel

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Licel works hard to support her family.

She has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from buy-and-sell dried fish. Licel is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to buy spare parts for the maintenance for her motorcycle transport business.

Licel has been sustaining her business activities through her past two loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

loans.name: Emelinda

texts.en:
Emelinda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy fishing materials for her fishing business.

Emelinda has been in this business for nine years. She earns more income from buy-and-sell fish.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials for her fishing business.

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza is 45 years old and married with four children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a buy-and-sell charcoal in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional sacks of charcoal to resell in her business.

Analiza has borrowed and paid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the buy-and-sell charcoal for three years, and earns an income from direct selling Avon and Natashia products.

She aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of charcoal to resell in her business.

loans.name: Ashgan Group

texts.en:
This group is called Ashgan and is composed of four women.  They applied for a loan of 90,000 YER from AMB. 

The president of the group is Hasna. She is 37 years old, married, and has seven children. She works selling cosmetics, perfumes, and incense as a door to door seller. She lives in Hodeidah, Yemen.  Hasna started her business two years ago in order to improve the income of the family. She will use the loan to buy more cosmetics and, in this way, will increase her working capital and improve her business. Her reason for applying for this loan is lack of capital. She faces many challenges in her business, including increasing her client base; she will use the profits to improve the quality of life for her family. For this reason, she applied for a loan of 30,000 YER from AMB.

Hasna looks forward to providing her family with a better life. Her dreams are to open a small shop for selling cosmetics for her clients in her area.

loans.use: to buy more cosmetics, perfumes, and incense

loans.name: Mustafa

texts.en:
Mustafa is a 29-year-old married man from Rafah. He lives with his wife in a very small house in the city. Mustafa started his own project ten years ago, which is selling chicken meat. It is a good business and the demand is always high. Mustafa would like to improve his business and expand it. 

Mustafa took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy a new refrigerator for his butcher shop. By taking this loan, Mustafa will be able to put more products in his store and increase the sales. Mustafa dreams to have more branches in the future. Mustafa appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a new refrigerator for his butcher shop.

loans.name: Victo

texts.en:
Victo is a single mother of five children, four of whom go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has a business of tailoring and has been in this business for six years. 

She has applied for a loan of 1,500,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more rolls of clothing materials. She generates additional income from selling piped water. She works in a shop seven days out of every week and sells on a retail basis.  Her major business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. 

She is aspiring to have a tailoring school and also to educate her children who go to school. She resides in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more rolls of clothing materials.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy has been running a hotel business for the past three years with a monthly income of KES 18,000, which she uses to support her family. She also practices small-scale farming to supplement her income. 

Mercy is applying for her fourth loan from VisionFund Kenya after repaying her previous loans successfully. She will use the loan to purchase milk, wheat flour, maize flour and sugar in bulk for her hotel. She will reinvest the proceeds into the business, buy food for her family and pay school fees for her child. 

She hopes to be financially stable and have a very happy family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings for planting.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
As a married parent of eight children, Teresita works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines and earns additional income from food vending.  Teresita is borrowing PHP 21,000 through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, noodles, dish washing powder, soy sauce, vinegar and other groceries for her general store business.

Teresita has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, noodles, dishwashing powder, soy sauce, vinegar and other groceries

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina is 40 years old and single.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines and earns additional income from raising pigs.  Angelina is borrowing PHP 24,000 through NWTF to buy additional food to sell for her food vending business.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her past 11 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional food to sell

loans.name: Zahida Saeed

texts.en:
Zahida Saeed is a 44-year-old widow, living in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. She is a religious lady and the mother of two sons and three daughters. The children are too young and fully dependent upon their mother. Her husband has suddenly died due to a heart attack. After the sudden death of her husband, she took responsibility regarding her children with courage. Earlier, her husband was running a garments shop; after his death, Zahida Saeed is looking after this shop with the help of her son.
 
She wants to increase her stock on a daily basis so she can generate maximum turnover against her efforts. Through additional income, she can easily cherish her children and prove herself to be a brave mother. Therefore, Zahida Saeed has requested a Kiva loan via Kiva’s field partner, BRAC Pakistan, so she can buy additional clothing for reselling.

She hopes that she can utilize this amount in a positive way for the growth of her business and savings as well.
Zahida Saeed dreams of a bright future for her children, establishment of her business, and a better living standard for her family.
She is very thankful to Kiva and its field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy clothing for reselling.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick is a 27-year-old single man. He operates a retail business where he makes bricks to sell. He has been involved in this business for three years. His business is located in a rural area and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge to be changes in price. He will use the KES 10,000 loan to buy equipment for making bricks and pay for labor. His business goal is to expand within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will have an improved living standard. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy equipment for making bricks and pay for labor

loans.name: Litchel

texts.en:
Litchel is married with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Litchel is 25 years old and has one child who is in school.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines. Litchel requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase fishing materials, such as net, bamboo, gasoline, etc.

Litchel has been in this business for nine years. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase fishing materials, such as net, bamboo, gasoline, etc.

loans.name: Celedonia

texts.en:
As a married parent of ten children, Celedonia works hard to support her family.

She has a coconut farming business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from selling vegetables. Celedonia is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies for her coconut farming business.

She successfully paid back her previous loan, and now requests a new loan to further build her business.

Celedonia has been sustaining her business activities through her past 16 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase fishing materials for her fishing business.

Victoria has been in this business for eight years. Victoria earns more income from making dried fish.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fishing materials for her fishing business.

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy fishing materials like fishing net, bamboo, wood, gasoline, etc for her fishing business.

Daisy has been in this business for 15 years and earns more income from her general store.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials like fishing net, bamboo, wood, gasoline, etc

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 56 years old and married with eight children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like snack foods, sugar, soap, noodles, shampoo, canned goods, and other groceries.

Evelyn has borrowed and repaid four loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from food vending.

She aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell like snack foods, sugar, soap, noodles, shampoo, canned goods, and other groceries.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and run two Fresh Life toilets.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy and sell of fruit and vegetables business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy more stock of fruits and vegetables to sell.

Corazon has been in this business for five years. Corazon earns more income from raising pigs and her general store.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Maira

texts.en:
Maira is 41 years old and married with three children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like soap, milk, sugar, etc.

Maira has borrowed and repaid 12 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for four years and earns additional income from food vending.

She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like soap, milk, and sugar

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is married with six children, four of whom go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has a business selling charcoal and has been in this business for 12 years. She has applied for a loan of 3,000,000 Uganda shillings (UGX) from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal.  

Betty works from home seven days out of every week and sells on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include transportation and seasonality. She is aspiring to become a wholesaler and also to build her rental houses. Betty resides with her family and has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Lukiya

texts.en:
Lukiya is married with five children, four of whom go to school. She has a business of selling silver fish, and has been in this business for a few months.

She has applied for a loan of 500,000 UGX to buy more bags of silver fish. She works at the market five days out of every week, and sells on wholesale basis. She doesn't have any other income-generating activity. 

Her major business challenges include seasonality and transportation. She is aspiring of owning a delivery van to ease in transportation, and buy a plot of land and build a house. 

She decided to join MCDT-SACCO because she gets timely loans. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bags of silver fish.

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred is 31 years old with two children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 21,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional household goods to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, etc.

Mildred has borrowed and paid four loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and earns additional income from buying and selling fish.

She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional household goods to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, and sugar

loans.name: Wango

texts.en:
Wango, a 54-year-old married mother of eight from Mwingi, Kenya, owns a business selling cereals and other grains. She is married to Musyoka. She has been selling cereals for the past ten years with a monthly income of KES 4,000. She currently lacks the capital needed to purchase items in bulk to restock her store. 

With a loan through VisionFund Kenya, Wango will be able to purchase cereals in bulk. She will then be able to have a fully stocked store that will attract more customers, generate sales, and create more profit. Additional income created will allow her to reinvest in her business, meet the needs of her family, and educate her youngest child since the rest are already grown up. 

In the future, Wango would like to eradicate poverty and uplift the living standards of her family.

loans.use: to buy assorted cereals in bulk

loans.name: Gemalyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Gemalyn works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from making dried fish. Gemalyn is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy fishing materials for her fishing business.

Gemalyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials for her fishing business.

loans.name: Om- Shouq Group

texts.en:
Om-Shouq is a group consisting of five women who live in Mokala, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 150,000 YER from AL-Amal Microfinance Bank.

Fayza is a 23-year-old married woman who lives with her spouse in Mokala, Yemen. She is the leader of the group. She lives in a very miserable condition in a very old house, but she didn’t give up. She studied until secondary school, but she couldn't finish because of the hard conditions of the family. 

Fayza decided to help her parents in improving the condition of the family. One of her goals is to help her father in renovating their house. She doesn't have money to do that, so she applied for a loan of 30,000 YER from AMB. She will use the loan to buy new doors and windows for the house. 

She looks forward to improving the condition of her family. She hopes to open a savings account in AMB.

loans.use: to buy new doors and windows for the house.

loans.name: Eden

texts.en:
Eden is 37 years old and married with three children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 50,000 loan through NWTF to buy items like shampoo and groceries to sell.

Eden has borrowed and repaid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for nine years and also earns income from motorcycle transport and buying and selling vegetables.

She aspires to save enough money to afford sending her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items like shampoo and groceries to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a rice retailing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell for her business.

Josephine has been in this business for 10 years. Josephine earns additional income from pig fattening.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia works hard to support her family. Ofelia is married and has a restaurant business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Ofelia has been in this business for 10 years now. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena is 46 years old and widowed with four children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell like canned goods, soap, milk, sugar, coffee and milk.

Rowena has borrowed and repaid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from buying and selling cashew nuts.

She aspires to save enough money to afford sending her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like canned goods, soap, milk, sugar, coffee and milk

loans.name: Erdenedalai

texts.en:
Mrs. Erdenedalai, 33 years old, lives with her husband, daughter and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Last year she began selling shoes, as it was more profitable than her previous businesses. Her husband is a truck driver and works for a mining company. Their daughter lives with their parents in the countryside, and their son stays at kindergarten during the daytime. 

She is requesting a loan of 5,000,000 MNT to buy spare parts for her husband's truck because from April on, mining sector activity increases, creating ample jobs for her husband to do. By doing so, she will help her family to improve their living standard.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for her husband's truck.
